Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Infrastructure for Prototyping Next-Generation Algorithms for Large-Scale Visualization, Data Processing and Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal #: 12-29185
PI(s): Silva, Claudio; Freire, Juliana; Iacono, John; Suel, Torsten; Vo, Huy
Institution: Polytechnic University of New York
Title: MRI/Acq.: Prototyping Next-Generation Algorithms for Large-scale Visualization, Data Processing and Analysis
Project Proposed:

This project, acquiring an instrument for prototyping the next-generation algorithms for large-scale visualization, data processing and analysis, facilitates the development and evaluation of next-generation algorithms and systems that leverage different hardware configurations. It consists of computational resources in the form of an SGI UV 1000 machine with 384 cores and four Tesla M2070 GPUs, and a small cluster composed of 32 nodes (384 cores total), each with two Tesla M2070 GPUs; and disk resources in the form of solid-state storage cards and an Isilon Storage Cluster. The instrumentation supports projects in various domains. The computer science projects include
- Dataflow architectures,
- Theoretical models of computation,
- Web search,
- Visualization, and
- Data mining;
While the application area research projects (undertaken with external collaborators) relate to
- Wildfire simulation,
- Bird migration simulation, and
- Climate science.

Broader Impacts:
The team plans to release the software developed as part of this project as open source, which carries potential for significant broader impact. The involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in the project provides mentoring opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project funded the development of a test bed for prototyping next-generation algorithms for large-scale visualization, data processing and analysis at the NYU Tandon School of Engineering. Our goal was to facilitate the development and evaluation of algorithms and systems that leverage different hardware configurations, including high-end GPUs.

We built the Brooklyn Research Cluster (BRC). The BRC allows users to easily allocate compute resources and obtain full control of those resources. This gives researchers the ability to spend more time focusing on research and less time-fighting system limitations and waiting for IT support. The BRC runs on OpenStack™ Software. Users interact with the system using a web interface, a command line interface, or a web API. The system automatically allocates machines, manage images, and builds virtual networks without involving IT or HPC personal. This is in contrast to existing shared resources at NYU where new servers need to be manually allocated, taking days to weeks. The project also included a HADOOP cluster and a high-performance SAN system.

This research infrastructure has supported dozens of projects, such as  novel tools and algorithms for urban planning and computational architecture, including Urban Pulse (The Economist, Oct 22, 2016) and Urban Shadows (The New York Times Upshot, Dec 21, 2016); new techniques and systems for spatio-temporal data indexing and exploration, including TaxiVis; information retrieval and web searching and mining tools and techniques, including ACHE and DDT; the development of new theoretical models of computation research (NSF award 1533564).

The equipment acquired through this grant supported the training of tens of students, many of whom come from underrepresented minorities. The projects, enabled by the infrastructure, contributed beyond computer science research into fields as diverse as urban science, biology, climate science, and transportation. We have made an effort to make our research contributions reproducible, and we have aimed to make our source code available as open source to enable others to build on our work. Many of the tools we have built are open source and available at https://github.com/ViDA-NYU.

This grant and its results have played an important role as part of NYU’s investment in the creation of a top engineering school in Brooklyn, NY. This investment is an important step towards establishing New York City as a major technology hub.
